text:
KEVIN MILLER: Okay, good afternoon everyone and thank you for coming to the session here. We're going to talk about VPC, Virtual
Private Cloud,

do a bit of a deep dive. I'm Kevin Miller, and I manage some
of the networking team,

I'm on the team that manages networking
features within EC2. So, that includes Virtual Private Cloud, our virtual private network service,
Direct Connect,

and other networking related capabilities
within EC2. So, before I dive into some of the
material today,

I do want to mention that there's
plenty of good content outside of this talk on VPC.

We're not going to be able to go through everything here today about VPC,
but there's a lot of content.

Most of these are talks from reInvent
back in November. The content is still pretty fresh and I definitely recommend it if
any of these topics sound interesting.

Check out the videos and the slides, they're all online, pretty easy to
find, so have at it.

And I just want to preface this by saying that we are going to be diving into
expert mode today. This is a deep dive, so expect us
to go fairly deep.

I'm going to be showing, you know,
command line parameters, how you configure VPC, and talk about

some of the deeper aspects of the service. So, get ready for that and I hope
I don't let you down.

There's really four things we're
going to be talking about today, and, you know, four different areas. The first is going to be some of
the routing

and private connectivity features
we have in Virtual Private Cloud, and this includes connectivity from
a data center or office

into Virtual Private Cloud. The second topic will be our VPC
peering feature.

This is a feature that allows you
to have multiple VPC that are interconnected in AWS, so
you don't have to

interconnect them outside of AWS
or route to them independently. So, we'll talk about that.

The third is I want to talk about
enhanced networking, which is a feature that we announce
about a year and a half ago

and really increases network performance
for instances that run in a VPC and use enhanced
networking.

So, want to make sure that all of you are able to take advantage of the
best networking performance you can, and that's really by using our enhanced
networking capabilities.

And finally, some of you may be customers
of AWS for a long time, thank you, and may be running in
our EC2-Classic environment

outside of VPC. We are trying to make it as easy
as possible for you to take advantage of all the great
features we have in the VPC,

and so we've built a feature called
ClassicLink that helps you adopt VPC if you have
a large Classic infrastructure.

So, I'm going to talk about ClassicLink and how you can use it to facilitate
an adoption of VPC.

Alright, so, just to level set so that we're all operating on the
same kind of understanding of the different networking capabilities,

in EC2 today we have two primary
networking modes, it's what we call EC2-Classic and VPC.

So, EC2-Classic, as the name implies,
was the capability set that we launched with EC2 initially
back in 2007.

You know, EC2-Classic provides a
very simple and straight forward networking capability. We assign the IP address and we provide
you the ability

to configure a security group - in
bound security groups - to limit access in or out of your instances.

And then in 2009 we launched Virtual
Private Cloud and since then we've been adding
a lot of capabilities.

Some of the more sophisticated networking features that our customers have told us are
important to them, and we've been adding those features
in, in VPC.

So, that includes things like the ability to have multiple virtual network
interfaces, what we call an ENI,

an Elastic Network Interface, multiple
IP address on your interfaces, routing, the ability to put security
rules both on ingress

and egress so you can limit traffic
leaving your machine and block, you know, potentially
malicious traffic,

the ability to have network ACLs, which is sort of a second layer of ACL capability
on top of VPC.

And then as I mentioned, enhanced
networking provides some pretty dramatic increases in
network performance in VPC.

So, we're pretty excited about that. Now, we recognize though that the
EC2-Classic environment provides

a very simple capability to get started, and so in 2013 we put this all together
in what we call

the Default VPC. So, if you've created an account
since 2013, or have not used EC2 in a region
since 2013,

you will have a Default VPC in that region. And with Default VPC, we give you
the ability to launch instances

without thinking about the private IP address or the public IP address, that's
all handled by us,

but you're able to start taking advantage of the Virtual Private Cloud features
at your own pace.
So, that's the Default VPC capability.

So, if you're wondering, you know,
am I in a Default VPC or not, it's actually pretty simple to figure this out. There's an API and command line tool
to query this.

I'm going to be showing lots of command
lines throughout the day, this is the AWS CLI set, and you'll
see lots of examples of this

throughout the day. In this case, we use the describe-account-attributes API and we specify that we're looking
specifically for Default VPC,

and you can see if you have a Default VPC it will come back as an account attribute
that you can then, you know, key off of.

Okay, so we're going to then move straight into routing and private connectivity and talk a little bit about how that
works in VPC.

So, we hear from a lot of customers that they have an existing infrastructure, they have, you know, maybe an existing
colo site, or an office,

or a data center, and they're looking
to figure out how do I start using AWS, and how
do I extend

the network that I have in my corporate
data center out and into AWS and EC2.

So, if you start with a corporate
data center, we recommend, you know, first thing
you do is you can create a VPC picking an IP address range

that doesn't overlap with your existing
data center so that you can have, you know, direct
private connectivity

back and forth between your corporate
data center and the VPC.

So, again, I'm showing you the commands
here at the bottom, you'll see this for pretty much all
of my slides, you'll see the exact set of commands
that I'm running

to do the operations that I'm showing
on the screen here. So, in this case what I've done is
I've created my VPC

in this 10.10 IP space, and then
I'm actually creating two subnets in the different availability zones.

So, each subnet and VPC lives in
a particular availability zone and this is so that we can provide, you know,

as much isolation as we can to ensure
you can continue to launch
in both availability zones, you know, even if one of the availability zones, you know, may not be able to launch at that moment.

So, we create two subnets, and then
I'm going to go ahead and start by just showing you this is the creating
of a VPN connection.

So, we support IPsec VPN, we support,
I think at this point,

more than a dozen different hardware
and software combinations of VPN devices that you might be
running in your data center.

And again, it's pretty much standard
IPsec with configuration templates

that we provide that help you get
started with, like I said, more than a dozen different combinations
of hardware and software.

So, again, I'm running just a few APIs. All of these APIs are also things
you can use

from our management console, you
can use the CLI tools or the SDKs directly if you prefer.

So, here I'm just creating what's
known as a VPN gateway and then I connect that gateway to my VPC.

I then create the customer gateway
where I specify my IP address, so this would be whatever IP address
your VPN endpoint
at your data center is connected to, and then I create a connection between those two.

So, now I have, you know, connectivity up, I configured my VPN router with the
configuration

to connect to AWS, and brought my
IPsec connectivity up. I'm going to go ahead and start running
some instances

and here we'll just start three instances
in both of my subnets. When you run an instance in VPC you
just tell us

what subnet you want that instance
to launch into and, you know, you can obviously specify that you want to run multiple instances
in one shot

and we'll deliver all three of them. Now, I don't quite yet have connectivity, so I'm going to walk through a couple
other configuration items

and then I'll show sort of all the
pieces to get connectivity finalized. So, earlier I showed the creation
of a VPN connection,

another mode of private connectivity
between VPC and your corporate data center is
our AWS Direct Connect product.

And so for customers who are looking
for a dedicated pipe, you know, be it 100 megabit, or a
gigabit, or even 10 gigabits,

or even multiple 10 gigabits, we
offer the AWS Direct Connect service

to allow you to create those connections. And those connections are either
a direct fiber connection or they're provided through one of
our AWS partners,

our APN partners, who provide circuit
backhaul basically from the Direct Connect locations
to wherever you're located,

to wherever your data center's located. And again, this is all API driven
from the AWS standpoint,

so you can use our APIs or command line tools to actually create the Direct Connect
connections,
tell us how much bandwidth you need, tell us where you're going to deliver that or where we should deliver that connection.

Direct Connect has, you know, more
than a dozen locations around the world, you know, including locations

accessing all of our regions. So, you can access any of our regions
through Direct Connect. And then you can create a private
virtual interface,

this is where you tell us all the
various parameters for the interface between us and you,

and then that's set up. Again, this is optional, if you just
want to get started with a VPN, or you don't even need private connectivity,

you don't need to go down this path,
but we do offer this and a lot of our customers take advantage of having this dedicated connection

particularly when you're looking
at a hybrid application where you really want to make sure
there's good connectivity between, you know, parts of your application
that are running in your data center

and parts that are living in AWS
and EC2.

Okay, so now I'm just going to configure
my routing table. And in VPC we have a virtual router.

The router in VPC is high capacity,
highly available, and some people ask me, well, where
is the second one,

where is the redundant router, and
the answer is there isn't, it's highly available, redundant,
all of that is abstracted,

you don't need to have two routers
to have that availability. All I have to do is create a route
though in my routing table

and basically specify that I want
the traffic to go to this gateway that we created earlier,
this VPN gateway.
So, now I have a complete working topology where I have instances running in my VPC

and a default route that goes back
to my data center, so any traffic that's not staying
within the VPC,

going between instances within that VPC, is actually just going to be default
routed out back home to my corporate data center.

And then likewise, I can have a route
in my corporate data center pointing the 10.10 traffic back to
the VPC and get that traffic in.

So, I want to talk briefly about
remote connectivity. I've demonstrated a couple of different
types of connectivity,

both VPN and Direct Connect. Some
customers, again, particularly when you're building
a hybrid architecture, they say, you know, they ask me,
what's the best practice,

how do I really build this for resiliency because I'm going to have maybe in
my database server running in my corporate data center

but all the web servers are living
in EC2 and I really want to make sure that we have good connectivity back and forth.

So, by default, when you create a
VPN connection, we actually give you two IPsec tunnels,

and that's just part of the standard
configuration. When you access the configuration
from our management console
or from the CLI tools, you will see both of those IPsec tunnels provided for you.

And what that maps to on our side
is endpoints that live in multiple availability zones.

So, we recommend for every customer, you know, good availability, sort of a baseline
of good availability,

is when you create a VPN connection, make sure that you provision both
of those tunnels.

We support both BGP routed as well
as statically routed tunnels, and we, again, for availability,
recommend using a BGP routed tunnel.

In this case, BGP is just the routing
protocol between you and us, it's not going out - there's no Internet
piece of it.

Some people see BGP and they think,
oh this is, like, Internet somehow. It's not, it's
just the routing protocol used

between our VPN router and your VPN router. And we give you configuration information
to help get that set up

and sort of almost copy and paste
to configure your router to speak BGP, you know, with us.

The reason we recommend BGP is that
BGP provides a hard, you know, layer for connectivity
check across that IPsec tunnel.

So, if anything happens to that IPsec
tunnel, you know, BGP, within 30 seconds, will detect
that there's been,

you know, an impairment and it will
automatically shift traffic over to the other tunnel.

You can configure these with static routes and we provide configurations to
make that as available as possible,

but again, I always recommend to
going to BGP for the best availability.

Now, a next step up that I would
say is a better set of, you know, sort of availability story
is not just

to create one VPN connection, but
actually to create two and have those terminate on different
routers on your side,

on your corporate, you know - whatever
your side is, whether it's an office or a corporate
data center. This allows for redundancy both against
failure of any

of the AWS devices, but also protects
against failure of devices at your side. And certainly in this case I recommend use of BGP

across all of these paths since now
you have four active paths and BGP will help make sure that
we're picking, you know,

an available path. And you can use, you know, various
aspects of BGP to sort of pin traffic to particular paths

if you prefer to have, you know,
a single ingress path or sort of a pair of ingress paths.

So, this is better availability. And then for customers who really
are running, you know, applications that they need,

they have to have a high degree of confidence that they'll have connectivity that
won't be subject to, you know, any vagarity of the Internet, you know,

the VPN connectivity is delivered
over the Internet. If you want to be protected against that, that's when we go straight to Direct Connect.

So, we look at Direct Connect, those
are, you know, hardwired or hard provisioned connections
from your network into VPC. And so this provides the best availability story.

And in this case, I'm showing both
Direct Connect plus a VPN backup, that all works just fine.

And again, this is where we use BGP
to make sure we pick the Direct Connect paths if they're available,

but if all else fails, we can fall
back to a VPN connection. With Direct Connect, each Direct
Connect connection you create

is actually a single connection to
a single hardware device running in our Direct Connect location,

but we support multiple - each of
our Direct Connect locations has multiple hardware devices so
that you can always establish

at least two redundant connections
to the same Direct Connect location. And then even further, Direct Connect
in some regions,

we have multiple Direct Connect locations
so that you can have both hardware redundancy as well
as geographic redundancy

for connections coming into our network. So, in some regions, literally, it's
two physically isolated locations.

Alright, so now, you know, we've
talked a lot about private connectivity, and again, for hybrid application use cases

this is what we see most commonly, you know, customers get started with something like this, but typically customers are also
looking for some form of

direct Internet connectivity out
of the VPC, what we call public connectivity. So, maybe it's an application that
is customer facing,
it's facing, you know, end consumers, and you want to have that, you know, direct Internet path into your VPC,

but you also want to have the private
path to your home network. And so this is all facilitated by
way of the Internet gateway.

So, you know, just like we created
the VPN gateway, you can create an Internet gateway,
attach it to you VPC.
And then what I'm showing here is that we're actually going to change our routing. We're just going to delete the default route.

We're going to point the default
route out to the Internet and then we'll just create a more
specific route to point to our home network.

So, instead of just sending any traffic that we don't have any other destination
for to our home network,

you know, we'll rout that traffic
out to the Internet and really selectively route traffic
to the home network.

And again, this is just a series
of CLI commands that you can run to do that, or the
management console.

And another optimization we provide
is actually to make it even simpler and avoid you having

to maintain your VPC routing table
with the prefixes that are showing up on your internal network,

we have a feature called Route Propagation. And again, showing you the commands
to enable this. What this does is simply says, any
kind of prefix

that I'm we at AWS receive from your
corporate data center that you advertise to us through
the routing protocol,

through BGP, any of those prefixes that I see we'll want to populate them into
the VPC routing table.

So, imagine that you have an existing, you know, subnet on your home network and you
decide tomorrow
that you need to add some IP space, you add that route on your corporate network, that route gets advertised to us,

we put it into your VPC routing table, and your instances then have full
connectivity without you having to make any additional API calls.

So, definitely recommended if your
corporate network is, you know, changing regularly.

Now, the other thing you can do with
VPC routing tables is that you can create a routing table
that is used for specific subnets

and put different entries into that
routing table. So, you know, previously I've talk
about a single routing table,

every VPC has a default routing table
that subnets will use unless you specify otherwise, and
so here I'm just demonstrating

that I'm going to create a subnet,
this 10.10.3 subnet on the left here,

and I'm going to create this subnet and I don't want it to have any connectivity
to my home network. You know, maybe these are my web servers

and the web servers never call home, there's no need for them to even
have network connectivity to the home network.

So, what I'm going to do is, you
know, create the subnet as I'm showing. I create a new routing table and
I associate that routing table

with the subnet. So, as soon as I associate the routing
table with the subnet, any traffic coming from instances
in that subnet

will be routed according to that
new routing table and will not use the default routing table.

So, I've associated the routing table and then I'm just going to create
a default route that points out to the Internet gateway.

And again, I haven't turned on Route
Propagation or put in any routes to my home network,

so there's literally no path for
this subnet to reach the home network at this point.

Now, some of the other things that you can do with multiple routing tables include
the ability to establish

something like a software VPN to
establish connectivity between VPCs. And so I'm going to show you actually how

VPC peering helps do this, later, but this is actually still somewhat
useful for particularly

when you're talking about connecting
VPCs across regions. So, in this case, what I'm doing is

I'm creating software VPN instances
in two of my subnets.

I have two VPCs, each of my VPCs
has a VPN instance running in a subnet, and then I'm
creating a customer routing table
and updating that routing table basically to specify that if VPC A wants to talk to VPC B

that traffic is going to be routed
through the VPN instance in VPC A and vice versa.

And so by doing so, then I can establish
a software VPC connection

between those two instances, and
now my two VPCs can exchange private IP communication
back and forth.

My private IP traffic will be exchanged
back and forth between these two VPCs using that
software VPN instance.

And, sorry, I mentioned this already before, but the way that this is done is
by updating - so, I've updated the default routing
table in both of these VPCs

to steer any of this traffic through
the VPN instances, and then the routing table for the
VPN instance subnets

just specifies that traffic can go
out to the Internet.

The other thing that can be done
with this capability with a second routing table or a
third routing table

is the ability to run either a NAT instance, some instance that provides NATing
functionality

or firewalling functionality, and, you know, many of our customers who are looking to have some sort of additional network monitoring
or network detection

on top of what we provide today, they'll use a NAT or firewall instance. And again, you can create a second
routing table

and that routing table, for the subnet
that has the NAT instance,

that table will specify the default route goes straight to the Internet gateway, and the default routing table for
all my other instances

will send the default, will specify
that that's instance ID. If you look at the first commend,
it's specifying

that the default route for any other
traffic in the VPC should send traffic to this one instance, which would be my NAT instance.

And that's how I can specify that traffic needs to be funneled through the
NAT instance, the firewall, to get out to the Internet.

Okay, so that provides some context
about, you know, private connections and routing in VPC.

I'm now going to talk a little bit
about VPC peering, which I sort of alluded to earlier.

And we see a couple major use cases
for VPC peering. One of the big ones is what I call
the shared services VPC.

So, you know, customers will ask
us, I'm creating multiple VPCs, I am thinking I have lots of applications,

and I want to create some isolation
between the applications, but I also have a set of things that
all my VPCs need to access.

So, that can things like authentication,
logging, monitoring, any kind of common services that
I provide across all my VPCs.

And so one of these cases we see
customers using VPC peering for is to create this kind of topology.

So, in this case, for example, my
VPC A might be my shared services VPC and with VPC A all of the other application
centered VPCs

will appear with that, and then they'll be able to access
my core services. So, you know, I'll administer core
services in VPC A

and then individual application owners
will administer the systems that run in any other VPCs.

Another use case that we see from
customers is just a simple sort of Dev, test,
prod hierarchy of deployments.

So, if I'm, you know, working on
my software, I'll use a Dev VPC, then once that's, you know, been committed,

it will be deployed out to my test VPC, and once all my tests pass I'll deploy
it out to my production VPC.

And one of the cool things about
doing this is that you can actually, you know,
create identical VPCS.

Your Dev, test, and prod can literally
use the same IP space or the same configuration and know
that, you know,

promoting it from B, to C, to D,
you're going to get the same experience, you're going to see the same network
that you'll see in production.

So you can really create, you know,
a test environment that replicates what I expect to
see in production.

So, how do I create a VPN - sorry,
a VPC peering connection? It's pretty straight forward.

We do support VPC peering connections
across accounts, so I'll show that in a little more
detail in a moment,

but there's a couple APIs that you can use. The first is just create VPC peering
connection,

and you basically specify the two
VPCs that you want to peer together. You have to then accept the connection
for the other VPCs.

So, you know, we make sure that there's
a handshake, basically, between the two VPCs that are getting
peered together,

and that handshake is essentially
the create followed by the accept. So, I first create it, I then accept
that new connection

using the peering ID. So, VPC peers will all have an ID
that looks like pcx-whatever.

And so in my second command I'm accepting
that peering connection.

Once the peering connection is established, then I just have to update my routing table. We talked about, obviously, a bunch
of routing updates earlier,

here I'm just updating my routing
tables on both sides to say that any traffic going to
the other VPC
goes through my peering connection. So, peering is again another target I can use,

just like earlier we used an Internet
gateway or a VPN gateway, now I can use a VPC peer as a route target.

And I mentioned you can do this across accounts. The difference when you do across
account is twofold.
One is that when you create the connection, you have to specify the peer owner account,
so that's the 12 digit AWS account ID. And that just makes sure that you know

who the peer account is owned by,
or the peer VPC is owned by. And then, in this case, the owner
of the other VPC,

that is the other owner account, needs to issue the accept to VPC
peering connection so that they are the one authorizing
the connection into that VPC.

So, you would just have to - you
know, obviously, if you own both accounts, you would just have to make sure
you're using the credentials

for the appropriate account when
you make these API calls so that we see that handshake between
your account,

your VPC, and the other account on
the other VPC. Otherwise, it's the same, you can
create routes

and you can exchange traffic across these. So, just a couple things to note
about VPC peering.

potentially changing over time, but today, we don't support security groups
across peerings. So, the workaround for controlling
access across VPC peerings is

that you can specify security group
rules using the IP prefix. I'm sorry - whoops, sorry.

Okay, alright, I'm just going to
put it right here. There we go.

Alright, so you can specify rules
by IP prefix to create security group rules that
will, like, restrict access

from one VPC peer to the other. Today, we don't support what we call
a "transit" capability.

So, you can imagine if you have three VPCs and you try to peer, you know, A
and B, and B and C,

A can't get to C through the B VPC. So, the way that you do that is you
can just create a full mesh.
So, you know, if I have four VPCs and I create kind of full mesh between - and I wanted to peer all of them,

then I would just create a full mesh
of VPC peers across all four of those. Now, finally, if you have two VPCs
and IP ranges overlap,

you're not going to be allowed to peer those so that we just - you know, it's
sort of a prevention,

protect against kind of an obvious situation where you won't be able to actually
fully communicate between those VPCs.

However, there's a finer point on
this which is that if you have two VPCs that have
different -

sorry, two VPCs that have overlapping ranges, both of those can peer with a third VPC as long as there's no overlap in
any of the -
okay, it definitely has a mind of its own - as long as there's no overlap between the two

that are directly making that peering
relationship you can actually have one VPC peered
with two others

that themselves overlap. And this is something we see done
when we have that sort of dev, test, and prod kind of use case where
you might have dev

and test and prod that have the same IP range, and you can just use routing tables
in the other VPC

to kind of steer traffic towards
the right VPC. And now, we're ready to advance.

So, you know, one other note here is that you can sort of combine two
of the concepts we've talked about today.

So, if I have a VPC peer and I want
to have some sort of NATing or firewall in between my VPCs, that
is definitely possible as well,

really you're just taking the same
concept that I was showing earlier where I create a second routing table,

and that routing table directs traffic
through the peer, and then I steer traffic from the
rest of my VPC, you know,

that wants to go to the peer, I steer
that to that NAT instance and then that sends it out through
the peering connection from there.

So, that allows me to have a middle
box sort of between my VPC A and VPC B.

Okay, cool. So, that's an update
on VPC peering, that's some of the things that you
can do with our VPC peering feature.

I want to turn attention now to enhanced
networking. So, when we talk to customers and
look at some of the workloads

that customers are running in EC2 and VPC, one of the things we noticed is that
a lot of applications

end up looking a lot like a request reply. So, that is, you know, maybe it's
my application server

is doing request reply to the database,
issuing queries and getting results from the database. That could be that I have a piece
of software

but a lot of the connections, you
know, look like request replies.

And when you look at the latency
of those request replies, there's a pretty strong correlation
between the latency

and the underlying packet rate that
you can obtain from the network. And so, when we looked at what was
adding latency

to some of our customer - you know,
sort of what part of network traffic really adds latency,

one of the things we saw is that
the packet per second capability of the instances really matters.

And so, this is really what motivated us to go down this path of enhanced networking and increase the packet rate that
we can support

in forwarding traffic through EC2,
and in doing so, reduce latency.

So, to start, you know, this is a
picture sort of what traditional network packet processing
has looked like in EC2.

And basically, I have my instance,
and in this case I have a couple elastic network adapters,

or elastic network interfaces, eth0
and eth1. And as traffic is coming from my
instance out to the network,

to somewhere else, that traffic is
coming from my virtual interface, my virtual NIC, from there it goes
into the virtualization layer,

the hypervisor underlying the instance, and then from there it's sent out
to the physical NIC,

you know, the NIC that has a physical
copper cable or fiber cable connected to it, out
into the rest of the network.

Again, this is what it sort of looked
like traditionally. With enhanced networking, we're using
a capability
but what it does is makes it possible for us to bypass some of that virtualization layer

and have your instance communicate
directly with the physical NIC

when it's sending network traffic. And so, what happens is there's really two things that have to change about this picture,
about the previous picture,

for this to work. One of them is that your instance
is running a driver which knows how to use this capability,
